docs.lead_paragraph: Daniel Patrick Moynihan, the Harvard professor and four-term United States senator from New York who brought a scholar's eye for data to politics and a politician's sense of the real world to academia, died yesterday at Washington Hospital Center in Washington, D.C. He was 76. The cause, a spokesman for the family said, was complications of a ruptured appendix, which was removed on March 11 at the hospital, where he remained.

headline.main: Daniel Patrick Moynihan Is Dead; Senator From Academia Was 76

docs.abstract: Daniel Patrick Moynihan, Harvard professor and four-term United States senator from New York, dies at age of 76; brought scholar's eye for data to politics and politician's sense of real world to academia; was always more a man of ideas than of legislation or partisan combat; was enough of politician to win re-election easily, and enough of maverick with close Republican friends to be occasional irritant to his Democratic party leaders; served in Senate from 1977 to 2001; before that he served two Democratic presidents and two Republicans; for more than 40 years, in and out of government, he was known for being among first to identify new problems and propose novel, if not easy, solutions; detailed examination of his career; photos (L)
docs.snippet: Daniel Patrick Moynihan, the Harvard professor and four-term United States senator from New York who brought a scholar's eye for data to politics and a politician's sense of the real world to academia, died yesterday at Washington Hospital Center in...
docs.section_name: Front Page; Washington; Obituaries; New York and Region

docs.lead_paragraph: AFTER anthrax spread through the mail in October 2001, the government began a crash program to develop drugs, vaccines and diagnostic tests to protect the nation from biological terrorism. The pharmaceutical industry pledged support. It seemed to be the dawn of a new defense industry, based on genes instead of jets. But with the nation now at war in Iraq, which is presumed to have biological weapons, the efforts to create a vibrant biodefense sector have had only partial success.

headline.main: Untested Companies Enlist in U.S. Biodefense

docs.abstract: Efforts in United States to create vibrant biodefense sector have left national security against bioterorism largely in hands of untested companies; about 100 biotechnology companies are trying to develop technology for detecting or fighting pathogens that may be used by terrorists or rogue nations; many are small companies, lured by government research money, that have never brought product to market successfully; Bush administration plan to spend some $6 billion over 10 years to buy and stockpile medicines to counter biological, chemical and radiological weapons will create guaranteed market for drugs; table of possible threats and companies working to counter them; photos (M)
